~start_node_property_cullen_source: Christopher Cullen, The Foundations of Celestial Reckoning, p. 52.
~relationship_property_explanation: Six yin lines × 24 = 144; derived from yarrow-stalk divination of the Pure Yin hexagram.
~end_node_property_note: Derived from 6 yin lines × 24 per line (Chthonic Reckoning).
~end_node_property_source: Christopher Cullen, The Foundations of Celestial Reckoning, p. 52.

~relationship_property_explanation: 81 is the numerical value representing the First Nine of the Yellow Bell; it is the fourth power of 3 and forms the harmonic foundation for calendrical pitchpipe construction.
~start_node_property_note: Fourth power of yang number 3 (3⁴ = 81); used as Day Factor (日法之數) in lunation calculations, representing the harmonic unit for subdividing lunar cycles.
~start_node_property_source: Christopher Cullen, The Foundations of Celestial Reckoning, p. 40.
~end_node_property_symbolic_meaning_en: Day Factor. The fourth power of the yang number 3 (3⁴ = 81), representing the harmonic origin of the calendrical system. This number embodies the cosmological and harmonic basis for the construction of calendrical units.
~end_node_property_cullen_quote_en: This number is the divisor of the fractional part of days in a (mean) lunation. As the text states, it is supposed to be derived from considerations of mathematical harmonics, for which the fundamental note is the one named ‘Yellow Bell’... The fourth power of the yang number 3 is 81, and when multiplied by 10... it represents the volume of the pitch pipe producing that note.
~end_node_property_original_text_zh: 太始元元，黃鐘之首九自乘為律首之數，以得日法之分。
~end_node_property_original_text_en: At the Origin Initiation, the First 9 of the Yellow Bell multiplies itself, which is the number of the first pitchpipe; one obtains the Day Factor.
~end_node_property_cullen_source: Christopher Cullen, The Foundations of Celestial Reckoning, p. 40
~end_node_property_name_en: First Nine of the Yellow Bell

~relationship_property_explanation: 81 is the Day Factor (日法); multiplied by 19 (Intercalation Factor) to yield the Concordance Factor 1539.
~end_node_property_note: Concordance Factor (會法), the product of Day Factor (81) and Intercalation Factor (19). It represents the core numerical cycle in which solar and lunar rhythms are coordinated in calendrical computation.
~end_node_property_source: Christopher Cullen, The Foundations of Celestial Reckoning, p. 41.
~start_node_property_note: Fourth power of yang number 3 (3⁴ = 81); used as Day Factor (日法之數) in lunation calculations, representing the harmonic unit for subdividing lunar cycles.
~start_node_property_source: Christopher Cullen, The Foundations of Celestial Reckoning, p. 40.

~start_node_property_cullen_source: Christopher Cullen, The Foundations of Celestial Reckoning, p. 43
~relationship_property_explanation: 2392 results from symbolic operations on 49 and other values within the image of the Great Expansion, producing the lunation factor.
~end_node_property_note: Lunation Factor (步法), represents the number of 1/81-day units per lunation, constructed through symbolic-numerical operations in the system of the Great Expansion.
~end_node_property_source: Christopher Cullen, The Foundations of Celestial Reckoning, p. 43
~start_node_property_source: Han shu 21a, p. 983
~start_node_property_symbolic_meaning_en: Symbolic structure used to derive the Lunation Factor. Encodes operations on the number 49 and related values—including multiplication by 2, 3, and 4, followed by additions of 19 and 1, and final doubling—producing 2392 units of 1/81 days per lunation.
~start_node_property_cullen_quote_en: The Lunation Factor 2392 is calculated through an extended symbolic chain: (49 × 2 × 3 × 4 + 19 + 1) × 2 = 2392. These numbers stem from the divinatory arithmetic of the Book of Change and cosmological construction in early Chinese thought… Extending the image of the Great Expansion, one obtains the Lunation Factor.
~start_node_property_original_text_zh: 大衍之數五十，其用四十有九……倍之以二象二，三之以三象三，四之以四象四，加十九象閏，又加一象用一，復倍之象再揲之法，以成步法。
~start_node_property_original_text_en: The number of the Great Expansion is 50; of these, 49 are used… this is doubled to represent 2, trebled for 3, quadrupled for 4, then 19 (symbolizing intercalation) is added, and 1 (symbolizing the ‘occupied one’) is added, then the whole is doubled for the two-handled manipulation. This yields the Lunation Factor.

~relationship_property_explanation: 19 is added to the product 49 × 2 × 3 × 4, symbolizing intercalation (象閏) within a 19-year cycle that regulates the insertion of lunar months.
~end_node_property_note: Lunation Factor (步法), represents the number of 1/81-day units per lunation, constructed through symbolic-numerical operations in the system of the Great Expansion.
~end_node_property_source: Christopher Cullen, The Foundations of Celestial Reckoning, p. 43
~start_node_property_note: Intercalation Factor (閏法之數), derived by summing the terminal numbers of Heaven (9) and Earth (10). It governs the cycle of seven intercalary months over every 19 solar years, reflecting the yin–yang reconciliation in calendrical cosmology.
~start_node_property_source: Christopher Cullen, The Foundations of Celestial Reckoning, pp. 40–41

~relationship_property_explanation: 1 is added symbolically as the 'occupied one' (象用一), representing the Dao that initiates but is not calculated—contributing to the symbolic harmony of the full expression.
~end_node_property_note: Lunation Factor (步法), represents the number of 1/81-day units per lunation, constructed through symbolic-numerical operations in the system of the Great Expansion.
~end_node_property_source: Christopher Cullen, The Foundations of Celestial Reckoning, p. 43
~start_node_property_note: Symbolically represents the ‘occupied one’ (用一), signifying the Dao. Added in the construction of the Lunation Factor before final doubling.
~start_node_property_source: Christopher Cullen, The Foundations of Celestial Reckoning, p. 43

~relationship_property_explanation: 2 is first applied as 49 × 2, initiating the symbolic sequence (象二) that begins the construction of the Lunation Factor: (49 × 2 × 3 × 4 + 19 + 1) × 2 = 2392.
~end_node_property_note: Lunation Factor (步法), represents the number of 1/81-day units per lunation, constructed through symbolic-numerical operations in the system of the Great Expansion.
~end_node_property_source: Christopher Cullen, The Foundations of Celestial Reckoning, p. 43
~start_node_property_note: Represents Earth (地) in yin–yang numerology; forms part of the Earthly (yin) sequence in the Book of Changes.
~start_node_property_source: Christopher Cullen, The Foundations of Celestial Reckoning, p. 41

~relationship_property_explanation: 2 is applied again at the end of the symbolic sequence, doubling the whole expression to represent the two-handed stalk manipulation (象再揲之法): (49 × 2 × 3 × 4 + 19 + 1) × 2 = 2392.
~end_node_property_note: Lunation Factor (步法), represents the number of 1/81-day units per lunation, constructed through symbolic-numerical operations in the system of the Great Expansion.
~end_node_property_source: Christopher Cullen, The Foundations of Celestial Reckoning, p. 43
~start_node_property_note: Represents Earth (地) in yin–yang numerology; forms part of the Earthly (yin) sequence in the Book of Changes.
~start_node_property_source: Christopher Cullen, The Foundations of Celestial Reckoning, p. 41

~relationship_property_explanation: 3 is applied as the next step in the symbolic construction: (49 × 2) × 3. It represents the yang sequence (象三), introducing celestial dynamics into the calendrical model.
~end_node_property_note: Lunation Factor (步法), represents the number of 1/81-day units per lunation, constructed through symbolic-numerical operations in the system of the Great Expansion.
~end_node_property_source: Christopher Cullen, The Foundations of Celestial Reckoning, p. 43
~start_node_property_note: Represents Heaven (天) in yin–yang numerology; forms part of the Heavenly (yang) sequence in the Book of Changes and the base of calendrical harmonic numbers.
~start_node_property_source: Christopher Cullen, The Foundations of Celestial Reckoning, pp. 40–41

~relationship_property_explanation: 4 is applied in the sequence as ((49 × 2 × 3) × 4), symbolizing structural formation (象四) through base yin–yang multiplication in calendrical construction.
~end_node_property_note: Lunation Factor (步法), represents the number of 1/81-day units per lunation, constructed through symbolic-numerical operations in the system of the Great Expansion.
~end_node_property_source: Christopher Cullen, The Foundations of Celestial Reckoning, p. 43
~start_node_property_note: Symbolic number associated with completeness and structural generation; used in calendrical operations such as 49×2×3×4 in the construction of the Lunation Factor.
~start_node_property_source: Christopher Cullen, The Foundations of Celestial Reckoning, p. 43

~start_node_property_cullen_source: Christopher Cullen, The Foundations of Celestial Reckoning, p. 43
~relationship_property_explanation: 49 is the foundational operand in the calculation of 2392: (49 × 2 × 3 × 4 + 19 + 1) × 2 = 2392. It represents the usable yarrow stalks in divination and initiates the symbolic algorithm.
~end_node_property_note: Lunation Factor (步法), represents the number of 1/81-day units per lunation, constructed through symbolic-numerical operations in the system of the Great Expansion.
~end_node_property_source: Christopher Cullen, The Foundations of Celestial Reckoning, p. 43
~start_node_property_note: The number of usable yarrow stalks in divination, foundational to the symbolic arithmetic used in calendrical construction.
~start_node_property_source: Christopher Cullen, The Foundations of Celestial Reckoning, p. 43

~relationship_property_explanation: 9 is the terminal yang number and serves as the sole unit comprising the symbolic structure 'Heaven's Terminal Number'.
~start_node_property_note: Used as the terminal number of Heaven (天之終數) in symbolic calendrical construction; forms part of the Intercalation Factor when summed with 10.
~start_node_property_source: Christopher Cullen, The Foundations of Celestial Reckoning, pp. 40–41
~end_node_property_cullen_quote_en: 9 and 10 are simply the last pair of numbers in the list, and when added they make 19. This is the number of civil years (1 Rule) containing seven intercalary months.
~end_node_property_original_text_zh: 天九地十，终数相加得十九。
~end_node_property_original_text_en: Heaven is nine, Earth is ten; summing their terminal numbers yields nineteen.
~end_node_property_cullen_source: Christopher Cullen, The Foundations of Celestial Reckoning, pp. 40–41
~end_node_property_meaning_en: yang, Heaven, nine, terminal yang number
~end_node_property_meaning_zh_simple: 阳, 天, 九, 阳数终点
~end_node_property_related_concepts_simp: 阳, 天, 九, 阳数终点
~end_node_property_related_concepts: 陽, 天, 九, 陽數終點
~end_node_property_meaning_zh: 陽, 天, 九, 陽數終點

~relationship_property_explanation: 10 is the terminal yin number and serves as the sole unit comprising the symbolic structure 'Earth's Terminal Number'.
~start_node_property_note: Used as the terminal number of Earth (地之終數) in symbolic calendrical construction; forms part of the Intercalation Factor when summed with 9.
~start_node_property_source: Christopher Cullen, The Foundations of Celestial Reckoning, pp. 40–41
~end_node_property_cullen_quote_en: 9 and 10 are simply the last pair of numbers in the list, and when added they make 19. This is the number of civil years (1 Rule) containing seven intercalary months.
~end_node_property_original_text_zh: 天九地十，终数相加得十九。
~end_node_property_original_text_en: Heaven is nine, Earth is ten; summing their terminal numbers yields nineteen.

~end_node_property_related_concepts: 陰, 地, 十, 陰數終點
~end_node_property_meaning_zh: 陰, 地, 十, 陰數終點

~start_node_property_meaning_zh_simple: 阳, 天, 九, 阳数终点

~start_node_property_related_concepts: 陽, 天, 九, 陽數終點
~start_node_property_meaning_zh: 陽, 天, 九, 陽數終點
~relationship_property_explanation: Heaven's Terminal Number is one of the structural components comprising the composite symbolic structure 'Sum of Heaven and Earth Terminal Numbers'.
~start_node_property_source: Han shu 21b, p. 991
~end_node_property_system: 陰陽 + 易象 + 歷法 system (yin–yang cosmology and calendrical intercalation)
~end_node_property_cullen_quote_en: 9 and 10 are simply the last pair of numbers in the list, and when added they make 19. This is the number of civil years (1 Rule) containing seven intercalary months, making a total of 235 months. The pattern of intercalations repeats at this interval.
~end_node_property_original_text_zh: 合天地之終數得閏法之數也。
~end_node_property_original_text_en: Joining the ultimate numbers of Heaven and Earth, one obtains the Intercalation Factor.
~end_node_property_cullen_source: Christopher Cullen, The Foundations of Celestial Reckoning, pp. 40–41

~relationship_property_explanation: 19 is the Intercalation Factor (閏法); multiplied by 81 (Day Factor) to yield the Concordance Factor 1539.
~end_node_property_note: Concordance Factor (會法), the product of Day Factor (81) and Intercalation Factor (19). It represents the core numerical cycle in which solar and lunar rhythms are coordinated in calendrical computation.
~end_node_property_source: Christopher Cullen, The Foundations of Celestial Reckoning, p. 41.
~start_node_property_note: Intercalation Factor (閏法之數), derived by summing the terminal numbers of Heaven (9) and Earth (10). It governs the cycle of seven intercalary months over every 19 solar years, reflecting the yin–yang reconciliation in calendrical cosmology.
~start_node_property_source: Christopher Cullen, The Foundations of Celestial Reckoning, pp. 40–41

~relationship_property_explanation: 1539, the Concordance Factor (會法), provides the numerical basis for the Triple Concordance system by aligning celestial, terrestrial, and anthropic cycles.
~start_node_property_note: Concordance Factor (會法), the product of Day Factor (81) and Intercalation Factor (19). It represents the core numerical cycle in which solar and lunar rhythms are coordinated in calendrical computation.
~start_node_property_source: Christopher Cullen, The Foundations of Celestial Reckoning, p. 41.
~end_node_property_symbolic_meaning_en: A calendrical system that coordinates three reckonings of time—celestial, terrestrial, and anthropic—based on the harmonizing cycle defined by the Concordance Factor (1539).
~end_node_property_system: 漢代曆法制度 (Han calendrical systems)
~end_node_property_cullen_quote_en: The number 1539 is the foundational cycle for the three Concordances: celestial, terrestrial, and anthropic.
~end_node_property_original_text_zh: 日法八十一，閏法十九，相乘以得會法。
~end_node_property_original_text_en: The Day Factor is 81, the Intercalation Factor is 19; their product gives the Concordance Factor.
~end_node_property_cullen_source: Christopher Cullen, The Foundations of Celestial Reckoning, p. 41
~end_node_property_meaning_en: triple time alignment: celestial, terrestrial, anthropic
~end_node_property_meaning_zh: 天統、地統、人統三種曆法節律的統一協調

~start_node_property_cullen_source: Christopher Cullen, The Foundations of Celestial Reckoning, p. 41
~start_node_property_meaning_zh: 太陽時間的統攝與調和
~relationship_property_explanation: This component is one of the three calendrical aspects (Celestial, Terrestrial, Anthropic) that constitute the Triple Concordance system..
~start_node_property_source: Han shu 21b, p. 991
~end_node_property_symbolic_meaning_en: A calendrical system that coordinates three reckonings of time—celestial, terrestrial, and anthropic—based on the harmonizing cycle defined by the Concordance Factor (1539).
~end_node_property_system: 漢代曆法制度 (Han calendrical systems)
~end_node_property_cullen_quote_en: The number 1539 is the foundational cycle for the three Concordances: celestial, terrestrial, and anthropic.
~end_node_property_original_text_zh: 日法八十一，閏法十九，相乘以得會法。
~end_node_property_original_text_en: The Day Factor is 81, the Intercalation Factor is 19; their product gives the Concordance Factor.
~end_node_property_cullen_source: Christopher Cullen, The Foundations of Celestial Reckoning, p. 41
~start_node_property_symbolic_meaning_en: The celestial aspect of the Triple Concordance system, corresponding to solar time cycles.
~start_node_property_cullen_quote_en: The Celestial Concordance aligns with the Xia calendar's 11th month, beginning at the winter solstice.
~start_node_property_original_text_zh: 天統者，以冬至之月為歲首。
~start_node_property_original_text_en: Celestial Concordance: the year begins with the month of the winter solstice.
~end_node_property_meaning_en: triple time alignment: celestial, terrestrial, anthropic
~end_node_property_meaning_zh: 天統、地統、人統三種曆法節律的統一協調

~start_node_property_cullen_source: Christopher Cullen, The Foundations of Celestial Reckoning, p. 41
~start_node_property_meaning_zh: 陰陽曆法與閏月機制的調和
~relationship_property_explanation: This component is one of the three calendrical aspects (Celestial, Terrestrial, Anthropic) that constitute the Triple Concordance system..
~start_node_property_source: Han shu 21b, p. 991
~end_node_property_symbolic_meaning_en: A calendrical system that coordinates three reckonings of time—celestial, terrestrial, and anthropic—based on the harmonizing cycle defined by the Concordance Factor (1539).
~end_node_property_system: 漢代曆法制度 (Han calendrical systems)
~end_node_property_cullen_quote_en: The number 1539 is the foundational cycle for the three Concordances: celestial, terrestrial, and anthropic.
~end_node_property_original_text_zh: 日法八十一，閏法十九，相乘以得會法。
~end_node_property_original_text_en: The Day Factor is 81, the Intercalation Factor is 19; their product gives the Concordance Factor.
~end_node_property_cullen_source: Christopher Cullen, The Foundations of Celestial Reckoning, p. 41
~start_node_property_symbolic_meaning_en: The terrestrial aspect of the Triple Concordance system, corresponding to lunar and intercalary time.
~start_node_property_cullen_quote_en: The Terrestrial Concordance begins in the 12th Xia month, aligning with midwinter but later than the winter solstice.
~start_node_property_original_text_en: Terrestrial Concordance: the year begins with the twelfth month.
~end_node_property_meaning_en: triple time alignment: celestial, terrestrial, anthropic
~end_node_property_meaning_zh: 天統、地統、人統三種曆法節律的統一協調

~start_node_property_cullen_source: Christopher Cullen, The Foundations of Celestial Reckoning, p. 41
~start_node_property_meaning_zh: 人事禮儀與曆法週期的配合
~relationship_property_explanation: This component is one of the three calendrical aspects (Celestial, Terrestrial, Anthropic) that constitute the Triple Concordance system..
~start_node_property_source: Han shu 21b, p. 991
~end_node_property_symbolic_meaning_en: A calendrical system that coordinates three reckonings of time—celestial, terrestrial, and anthropic—based on the harmonizing cycle defined by the Concordance Factor (1539).
~end_node_property_system: 漢代曆法制度 (Han calendrical systems)
~end_node_property_cullen_quote_en: The number 1539 is the foundational cycle for the three Concordances: celestial, terrestrial, and anthropic.
~end_node_property_original_text_zh: 日法八十一，閏法十九，相乘以得會法。
~end_node_property_original_text_en: The Day Factor is 81, the Intercalation Factor is 19; their product gives the Concordance Factor.
~end_node_property_cullen_source: Christopher Cullen, The Foundations of Celestial Reckoning, p. 41
~start_node_property_symbolic_meaning_en: The anthropic aspect of the Triple Concordance system, corresponding to ritual time and human scheduling.
~start_node_property_cullen_quote_en: The Anthropic Concordance follows ritual precedence, aligning the year start with the 1st month for human affairs and ceremonial rhythm.
~start_node_property_original_text_en: Anthropic Concordance: the year begins with the first month of spring.
~end_node_property_meaning_en: triple time alignment: celestial, terrestrial, anthropic
~end_node_property_meaning_zh: 天統、地統、人統三種曆法節律的統一協調

~relationship_property_explanation: 5 symbolizes the utmost of yang numbers: it is the final odd number included in calendrical calculation, completing the active sequence in symbolic cosmology.
~start_node_property_note: Symbolically represents the ‘occupied one’ (用一), signifying the Dao. Added in the construction of the Lunation Factor before final doubling.
~start_node_property_source: Christopher Cullen, The Foundations of Celestial Reckoning, p. 43
~end_node_property_cullen_quote_en: The ‘occupied one’ (用一) is added before doubling. This represents the Dao in the symbolic structure of the Lunation Factor.
~end_node_property_original_text_zh: 五十以象之，其用四十九，而弃一以象道。
~end_node_property_original_text_en: One is added but not used in calculation, representing the Dao.
~end_node_property_cullen_source: Christopher Cullen, The Foundations of Celestial Reckoning, p. 43
~end_node_property_related_concepts_simp: 用一, 占位, 元始, 本体, 起始之数
~end_node_property_related_concepts: 用一, 占位, 元始, 本體, 起始之數
~end_node_property_meaning_zh: 元始, 一體, 虛無, 生發之源
~end_node_property_system_tags_zh: ['道本體','象數系統','哲理宇宙論']
~end_node_property_system_tags_zh_simple: ['道本体','象数系统','哲理宇宙论']

~relationship_property_explanation: The moon, represented through poetic terms such as śaśin and soma, symbolizes the number 1 in Bhūta-saṃkhyā notations.
~start_node_property_note: Symbolically represents the ‘occupied one’ (用一), signifying the Dao. Added in the construction of the Lunation Factor before final doubling.
~start_node_property_source: Christopher Cullen, The Foundations of Celestial Reckoning, p. 43
~end_node_property_original_text_zh: 有兔者、蘇摩、水滴、冰霜之光、夜之造者、雪中行者、有鹿斑者、陰影之持者等皆為月亮之名。
~end_node_property_original_text_en: śaśin, soma, indu, prāleyāṃśu, rajanīkaraḥ, himagu, mṛgāṅka, and kalādharaḥ are all names of the moon.
~end_node_property_meaning_en: ['hare-marked','soma','drop','beam of frost','maker of night','snow-goer','deer-marked','holder of phases']
~end_node_property_meaning_zh_simple: ['有兔者','苏摩','水滴','冰霜之光','夜之造者','雪中行者','有鹿斑者','阴影之持者']
~end_node_property_meaning_zh: ['有兔者','蘇摩','水滴','冰霜之光','夜之造者','雪中行者','有鹿斑者','陰影之持者']
~end_node_property_original_text_tr: śaśin somaś cenduś ca prāleyāṃśurajanīkaraḥ himagur mṛgāṅkaś ca kalādharaś caiva candramāḥ
~end_node_property_original_text_sa: शशिन् सोमश्चेन्दुश्च प्रालेयांशुरजनीकरः । हिमगुर्मृगाङ्कश्च कलाधरश्चैव चन्द्रमाः ॥
~end_node_property_petrocchi_quote_en: All these are synonyms or poetic epithets of the moon, and by extension are used to represent the number one in Bhūta-saṃkhyā notations.

~relationship_property_explanation: 5 symbolizes the utmost of yang numbers: it is the final odd number included in calendrical calculation, completing the active sequence in symbolic cosmology.
~start_node_property_note: Represents Earth (地) in yin–yang numerology; forms part of the Earthly (yin) sequence in the Book of Changes.
~start_node_property_source: Christopher Cullen, The Foundations of Celestial Reckoning, p. 41
~end_node_property_cullen_quote_en: The number 2 is part of the Earthly (yin) sequence in the Book of Changes.
~end_node_property_original_text_en: The even numbers—2, 4, 6, 8, 10—are assigned to Earth (yin).
~end_node_property_cullen_source: Christopher Cullen, The Foundations of Celestial Reckoning, p. 41
~end_node_property_related_concepts_simp: 二, 地之数, 偶数, 阴象
~end_node_property_related_concepts: 二, 地之數, 偶數, 陰象
~end_node_property_meaning_zh: 陰性, 承載, 雙數, 靜定

~relationship_property_explanation: 5 symbolizes the utmost of yang numbers: it is the final odd number included in calendrical calculation, completing the active sequence in symbolic cosmology.
~start_node_property_note: Represents Heaven (天) in yin–yang numerology; forms part of the Heavenly (yang) sequence in the Book of Changes and the base of calendrical harmonic numbers.
~start_node_property_source: Christopher Cullen, The Foundations of Celestial Reckoning, pp. 40–41
~end_node_property_cullen_quote_en: The number 3 belongs to the Heavenly (yang) sequence and forms the base of calendrical harmonic constructions.
~end_node_property_original_text_en: The odd numbers—1, 3, 5, 7, 9—are assigned to Heaven (yang).
~end_node_property_cullen_source: Christopher Cullen, The Foundations of Celestial Reckoning, p. 40
~end_node_property_related_concepts_simp: 三, 天之数, 奇数, 阳象
~end_node_property_related_concepts: 三, 天之數, 奇數, 陽象
~end_node_property_meaning_zh: 陽性, 生發, 三才, 奇數

~relationship_property_explanation: 5 symbolizes the utmost of yang numbers: it is the final odd number included in calendrical calculation, completing the active sequence in symbolic cosmology.
~start_node_property_note: Symbolic number associated with completeness and structural generation; used in calendrical operations such as 49×2×3×4 in the construction of the Lunation Factor.
~start_node_property_source: Christopher Cullen, The Foundations of Celestial Reckoning, p. 43
~end_node_property_cullen_quote_en: The number 4 symbolizes structuring multiplicity in the divinatory calculation of the Lunation Factor.
~end_node_property_original_text_zh: 四之以四象四，以成步法。
~end_node_property_original_text_en: Multiplied by 4 to form the structure of the Lunation Factor.
~end_node_property_cullen_source: Christopher Cullen, The Foundations of Celestial Reckoning, p. 43
~end_node_property_related_concepts_simp: 四, 成形, 四象, 宇宙结构
~end_node_property_related_concepts: 四, 成形, 四象, 宇宙結構
~end_node_property_meaning_zh: 結構, 完滿, 生化, 穩定

~start_node_property_cullen_source: Christopher Cullen, The Foundations of Celestial Reckoning, p. 43
~relationship_property_explanation: 49 symbolizes the operational count derived from the Great Expansion system (大衍之數), forming the numeric foundation of the symbolic calendrical sequence.
~start_node_property_note: The number of usable yarrow stalks in divination, foundational to the symbolic arithmetic used in calendrical construction.
~start_node_property_source: Christopher Cullen, The Foundations of Celestial Reckoning, p. 43
~end_node_property_cullen_quote_en: The number of the Great Expansion is 50; of these, 49 are used…
~end_node_property_original_text_zh: 大衍之數五十，其用四十九……
~end_node_property_original_text_en: The number of the Great Expansion is 50; of these, 49 are used…
~end_node_property_cullen_source: Christopher Cullen, The Foundations of Celestial Reckoning, p. 43
~end_node_property_meaning_en: usable yarrow stalks, symbolic count, calendrical base
~end_node_property_meaning_zh_simple: 可用蓍草, 象征数, 历法根基
~end_node_property_related_concepts_simp: 大衍, 蓍草, 象数, 筮法, 天地生成
~end_node_property_related_concepts: 大衍, 蓍草, 象數, 筮法, 天地生成
~end_node_property_meaning_zh: 可用蓍草, 象徵數, 曆法根基
~end_node_property_system_tags_zh: ['象數系統','天地生成','筮法結構']
~end_node_property_system_tags_zh_simple: ['象数系统','天地生成','筮法结构']
